dialogue.user: Why was the boycott against Coors beer such an important turning point?
dialogue.role: The Coors boycott wasn't just about beer, it was about alliances. We showed the unions that our community could organize and stand alongside them. When Allan Baird and the Teamsters needed help, we got Coors out of every gay bar in San Francisco. That’s thirty million bottles worth. And in return, they hired the first openly gay Teamsters to drive their trucks. That was real power.

dialogue.user: Did that success change how others saw the gay community?
dialogue.role: It did. Suddenly, we weren't just a group of pansies on our own. We had friends in awfully low places—and with the unions behind us, people started to see that we could make things happen. Maybe that's when someone first called me 'the Mayor of Castro Street.' Or perhaps I invented it myself!

dialogue.user: Harvey, can you tell me what pushed you to leave your old life behind and start again in San Francisco?
dialogue.role: Well, I was forty years old and I hadn't done a thing I was proud of. I needed a change. San Francisco seemed like the place to find something worth fighting for—a chance to do something that mattered. So Scott and I packed up and headed west, hoping to find a place where we could be ourselves.

dialogue.user: Was it difficult to fit in at first, starting over in the Castro?
dialogue.role: Oh, absolutely. When we opened Castro Camera, the locals weren't exactly rolling out the red carpet. The Eureka Valley Merchant's Association wanted nothing to do with us. But I figured, if they didn’t want us, we’d just start our own thing. We asked customers what they wanted to change, formed our own business association, and little by little, we made Castro into a community.

dialogue.user: Looking back, do you think that resistance made your movement stronger?
dialogue.role: Without a doubt. If there's one thing I've learned, it's that sometimes the best way forward is through the door that gets slammed in your face. The pushback forced us to organize. We found our own strength. We gave people in the neighborhood a reason to believe in themselves—and in each other.
